activity-description.narrative: Beneficiaries of the decisions from the Land and Dismissals Comissions

description.narrative: Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

1. The Land and Dismissals Commissions have capacity to aggregate and dissegrate cases and protect documentation. 2. The Transitional Justice Woorking Group of the National Dialogue Conference has capacity to define appropriate recommendations regarding transitional justice and to improve TJ legislation 3. Representatives of excluded and marginalized communities, such as Al-Houthis, citizens of southern governorates, victims, tribesmen etc. included in consultation process on transitional justice and national reconciliation 4. Staff of MoLA gained knowledge on transitional justice in general and truth commissions in particular and what is important to create relevant laws and by-laws.

comment.narrative: 1. Draft Law on Transitional Justice and National Reconciliation is not adopted 2. The Land and Dismissals Commissions do not have capacity to achieve their mandates. 3. Inexistance of consultations on transitional justice. It is widely percieved that some communities, such as Al-Houthis, citizens from Souther Governorates, victims etc. are excluded from societal processes. 4. CSOs, representatives of government and society in general do not have knowledge on TJ.

• up to 30 representatives of NGOs trained in project cycle management, financial management and strategic planning management • Up to 30 representatives of NGOs trained 1) in international humanitarian law and human rights law and 2) how to document and report human rights violations and at least 12 of them document and report human rights violations • # of Yemen specialists trained how to provide psychosocial and (para)legal assistance to people in need and at least 12 of them implement gained knowledge • # of Yemen CSOs trained how to implement community security related activities and UNDP made partnership with up to two CSOs • # of government specialists trained in international humanitarian law and human rights law and implement gained knowledge in every day work • # of victims/witnesses of human rights violations interviewed • # of women and girls victims of war and SGBV interviewed • # of victims received psychosocial assistance (particular focus will be given to women and girls victims of war and SGBV) • # of people in need received (para)legal assistance • Community Safety and Security Plans (CSSP) developed in up to 4 locations • CSSP started being implemented in up to 2 locations • The Land and Dismissals Commissions inserted at least 100,000 files into database. • # of Land and Dismissals Commissions’ employees trained in reparations • # of NGOs submitted project proposals to implement human rights/protection related activities • Needs assessment on security and justice conducted – at least 1,000 participated in needs assessment • # of consultative events organized and at least 100 citizens participated in consultative events on transitional justice, human rights, community dialogue, reconciliation etc. • At least one vocational training organized focusing 100 women victims of war and SGBV • UNDP TJ strategy created • Partnership with # of local and international NGOs to implement activities in local areas signed (activities: document and

The TJ Law has been amended
Around 500 citizens participated in the transitional justice educational events and additional around 500 citizens have participated in the consultation process on the draft TJ Law (related to the activity result 1.8).
More than 100 recommendations were collected during the consultation process and inserted in the draft TJ Law.
62 MoLA staff have been trained in transitional justice mechanisms and transitional justice legal drafting. 10 of them were directly involved in redrafting the TJ Law, based on gained knowledge (related to the activity result 1.2.)
The MoLA TJ office has been established.
62 MoLA staff have been trained in transitional justice mechanisms and transitional justice legal drafting. 10 of them were directly involved in redrafting the TJ Law, based on gained knowledge (related to the activity result 1.1.)
All 30 representatives of MOLA who were trained in TJ, conflict resolution and strategic communication used attained knowledge while communicating with public or implementing TJ activities.
Out of 30 MoLA staff who have been trained to become independent facilitators, 15 have been facilitating trainings, workshops and consultation process on the TJ Law.
Partnership created with the three NDC’s working groups (rights and freedoms, Sa’ada issue and transitional justice working groups), to create recommendations relevant to their mandates.
Programme concept papers 1) on gender and TJ, 2) reparations and 3) NGOs finalized.
Based on the project’s support more than 60 CSOs implemented TJ activities (mostly raising awareness activities at local community level)
The project and MOLA staff gave more than 10 interviews to various MEDIA outlets. Local and regional TVs aired in live the project’s events. MoLA deputy minister and a project’s member participated in a TV talk show (Al-Saeda TV)
More than 400 citizens participated in educational events on transitional justice and national reconciliation.
More t

description.narrative: Accountability - local government finance

Output 1: (1) Extent to which sub-national governments/administrations which have functioning planning systems ((i) participatory - developed with stakeholder consultation; (ii) harmonized with the national plan where existing; (iii) have a defined list of actions; (iv) and receive approval of sub-national representatives) (2) Extent to which sub-national governments/administrations which have functioning budgeting systems ((i) must be linked to sub-national plans; (ii) go through an approval system allowing for discussions by sub-national representatives and stakeholders (iii) be approved by the sub-national government/administration representatives; (iv) be used as basis of sub-national resource disbursement and financial reporting) (3) Extent to which sub-national governments/administrations which have functioning monitoring systems (i) the monitoring system must have an established period for assessment and review; (ii) based on clear and agreed targets and indicators; (iii) a predictable process for engagement and reporting to stakeholders and (iv) evidence that monitoring activities are being carried and recorded.)
Output 3 (1) % of people support the new decentralisation system (2) Level of satisfaction with the new local governance structure

comment.narrative:
Output 1 (1) 1 (year 2014) (2) 1 (year 2014) (3) 1 (year 2014)
Output 3 (1) TBC (year 2014) (2) TBC (year 2014)

1- 1 Mobile Team (central), 5 District Facilitation Teams (governorate) and 14 Core Teams (district) have better capacity in budgeting and planning 2- 14 prioritised projects (1/district) identified in a participatory manner particularly women and young male and female. 3- Peace and Development Grant system is finalized to support 14 districts

A plan was developed for the four District Facilitation Teams (DFTs) to conduct assessment to identify the needs of office equipment at 14 districts. The assessment of the equipment needs and identification of potential members of core teams have been taking place from the last week of September to the second week of October. • Established five DFTs, which consist of six to seven people in four governorates (Hadramout, Hajjah, Taiz, and Socotra). Total number of DFTs members are 32 and 8 are female. • Each District Facilitation Team includes at least two Civil Society Organisations representatives recommended by UNFPA. • Official launching events took place with the Ministry of Local Administration (MoLA) and the Governors in Taiz and Hadramout. • Formation of 14 Core Teams will be conducted in October The process of the district planning has been completed for the year of 2014. The Peace and Transition Support Project (PTSP) started collecting the plans developed by the District Governments in 14 target districts. The review of the plan and consultation will be done in November and December. Options of grant systems have been identified. Discussions with the MoLA, Ministry of Finance (MoF) and Central Bank are on-going to identify the most efficient ways to channel grants to the districts using the government budget allocation system. An agreement for the grant system would be signed upon the district plan review and identification of priority projects in participatory manner at the district.
Initial discussions took place with MoLA in confirming the area of support that MoLA would need. The review and preparation of legal framework for local governance would be launched upon the first draft of constitution is available (the draft constitution is expected to be available in November).
Diagnostics of core government functions for decentralisations under the federal system was planned initially at the end of August. However, owing to the security sit

description.narrative: - # of women and men improved their knowledge pertaining to business creation and development - # of women and men finalized a quality business plan - # of women and men participating in business training - # of youth obtained a financial identity through opening of a bank account - # of youth linked with financial resources and services (access to loan) - # of youth placed - # percentage of women - # of youth who received career guidance support based on Tamheed assessments

comment.narrative: - 48% of the youth are neither in education nor employment or training - Limited resources, employment and access to market opportunities for youth - Weak partnership with the private sector for business development and job promotion - Weak youth business skills - Weak national capacities for economic empowerment and employment creation - Yemen is the lowest in the Gender Gap Index since 2006

• Activity 2: Indicators: project review conducted and validated Targets: lessons learnt of livelihoods activities in Saada documented through project review
• Activity 3: Indicators: # of MSMEs established through skills development and capitalisation Targets: 144
• Activity 4: Indicators: project review of 3x6 approach conducted Targets: lessons learnt of 3x6 approach in crisis setting documented through project review
• Activity 5: Indicators: innovative business solutions launched Targets: 10
• Activity 7: Indicators: # of projects supported through Diaspora and private sector partnership Targets: 2

Between January and March 2016, YEEP has created 166 direct employment opportunities for youth, including 27% of women, through the capitalisation of micro-social businesses that contribute to social impact in addition to generating income. Youth also benefited from improved business and life skills through training, coaching and business advisory services provided, that will improve their business resilience. A MoU was signed with the Arab Association in Singapore and a Goodwill Ambassador appointed, Dr Saad ben Taleb, former Minister of Industry and Trade, to promote the Yemen Our Home initiative in Southeast Asia amongst the Diaspora community. Similarly, partnerships have been concluded with Sabafon to directly fund the establishment of a youth-run social business in Sana’a responding to local health needs and outreach to associations/companies pursued to identify areas of mutual interests for in-kind or financial contributions. Through technical assistance, the Business Support Centre established in 2015 finalised its work plan to expand its operations and strategic relevance through prospective studies and developing a one-stop-shop oriented solutions centre for aspiring and existing young entrepreneurs.
During Q2, two projects were funded through the Yemen Our Home initiative by SabaFon and Al Kuraimi with preparations led towards their implementation. the BSC continued to run its programme in Sana'a to support entrepreneurs through innovation-oriented workshops such as the Yemen Business Breakfast.
- At least one project on social business is developed and supported through Diaspora and private sector partnership.

20 midwives were trained in businesses management and community mapping. They have also received refresh training in reproductive health and received specific equipment to start their own private clinics. Other 12 trained midwives also received extra equipment supporting their established clinics”.

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to

Community Livelihoods to support communities to better be able to manage local risks and shocks for increased economic self-reliance and enhanced social cohesion
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Community livelihoods and productive assets are improved to strengthen resilience and economic self-reliance

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1- 100 Community resilience plans are developed. 2- At least 14,000 vulnerable and food insecure individuals indirectly benefiting from emergency income generating revenues that provides immediate income 3- At least 21,000 men and women indirectly benefiting from improved skills to establish community-oriented social businesses for self-reliance. 4- 28,000 men and women indirectly benefiting from technical and economic capacities built on agriculture value chains

comment.narrative:
Limited entrepreneurial pathways available in rural (remote) areas for affected/vulnerable groups
Business associations/economic institutions have a limited technical and operational engagement in enterprise recovery

At least 21,000 men and women indirectly benefiting from improved skills to establish community-oriented social businesses for self-reliance
Completion of a business capacity assessment targeting two business association to define capacity development response

Preparatory work to set up local partnerships was undertaken during Q2 and two implementing partners were identified for the implementation of the 3x6 approach: SDF (Hajjah, Hodeidah Governorates) and FAF (Abyan Governorate). Contracting and implementation in the field will be finalized in the next quarter, including the finalization of the Lahj contracting. A market assessment was initiated in Hajjah and Hodeidah to identify micro-social business opportunities for the 3x6 beneficiaries. Findings as well as Lahj and Abyan results will be consolidated in a report in the next quarter with dissemination workshops at the local level involving stakeholders, including the business trainers to link the market assessment outcomes with the content of the business training. A business capacity assessment was also launched to review existing and desired capacities of the Hodeidah Chamber of Commerce and Yemen Business Club in Aden to support crisis-affected SMEs. Two consultants were contracted and finalized their methodology. The assessment will be completed in the next quarter.

- At least 9,800 men and women indirectly benefiting from improved skills to establish community-oriented social businesses for self-reliance. - 1,400 beneficiaries are engaged in cash for work activities and enrolled in business and life and skills training and 800 business created. - Two business associations’ capacity needs assessed and capacity gaps addressed through capacity building programmes.

- At least 9,800 men and women indirectly benefiting from improved skills to establish community-oriented social businesses for self-reliance. - 1,400 ( 596 women ) beneficiaries are engaged in cash for work activities and enrolled in business and life and skills training and 800 business created. - Two business associations’ capacity needs assessed and capacity gaps addressed through capacity building programmes

Outcome 1 Output 1.1 300 businesses are created. At least 2,100 men and women indirectly benefiting from improved skills to establish community-oriented social businesses for self-reliance
Outcome 2 Output 2.2 Implementation of capacity building plans for two business associations

ERRY Output 2.1 (i) 0 (ii) 1 (iii) In 2016, the baseline and target are same for this indicator.

Q3 2016 The project was launched from March 2016 and thus the project has not delivered any progresses that can be measured by the indicators. The achievements in Q3 were following: - Two technical specialists were recruited for managing this result. - A potential partner to deliver activity results under this output was identified and specific deliverables were almost agreed (a draft agreement (letter of agreement) was ready). Implementation through the partner will be started in July 2016.

• 87 VCCs will be established (10 VCCs will be Reactivated and 77 VCCs will be formatted) • 87 of Community Resilience Plans will be developed • At least 87 of self-help initiative will be implemented. • Provide block grants for and implementing 210 community based initiatives
• 8 recovery plans will be developed • 4 projects from recovery plans in the district level will be implemented • Level of capacity of sub-national governments for planning and monitoring delivery of basic services is 2 = very partial capacity • 20% of VCCs members who responded positively with local authorities’ service delivery

Quarter 3 - Formation of 87 VCCs, 87 of Community Resilience Plans and 87 of self-help initiative, 230 of community-based Initiatives, 8 recovery plan with 8 project in district level - - 63 VCC formed, 63 resilience plans developed, 15 self help initiatives done, and 186 community based initiatives implemented, and 5 recovery plans developed.
Quarter 2 (a) 186 (60 in Abyan, 50 in Lahaj, 40 in Hajjah and 34 in Hudaydah) Village cooperative councils (VCCs) formatted/reactivated. (b) 186 community resilience plans developed. (c) 330 self-help initiatives from the resilience plans identified and conducted until March 2017. (d) 63 Matching grants as contribution to implement during Q1 a Q2 of 2017 in sex districts based on the community plans. (e) 60 Matching grants as contribution to implement during Q3 of 2017 in districts based on the community plans. (f) The recovery plans work started in Bani Qais district in Hajjah and the plan under review and in the rest of the districts teams were formed and after Eid Holladay they will be start to complete of preparing for recovery plans .
Quarter 1 . 63 VCC were established in Abyan and Lahj.
. 63 community resilience plans were developed in lahj and Abyan.
. 73 Self-help initiative Still on process until the end of the year in abyan and Lahj.

capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: UNDP Project Management

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

(i) Completion of start-up/launching the project within Q2 2016 as agreed in the Dead Sea Workshop (ii) Quarterly work plan review (iii) Quarterly issues and risk log update (iv) Quarterly project narrative report

comment.narrative: (i) 9 new posts were established in UNDP ERRY project organogram, Identification and endorsement of target districts by the government and donor. (ii) Three year's results framework was a part of the Description of Action (Annex 1) and the first annual work plan expected before the ERRY Joint Programme Induction Workshop in Djibouti (June) (iii) Original issue and risk log developed in the Dead Sea workshop in January (iv) A quarterly narrative report using ATLAS will be submitted in two weeks after every quarter

(i) Completion of start up by the end of June 2016 and implementation will start from July (ii) Initial annual work plan developed in June and reviewed in the beginning of October. (iii) Issue and risk log updated in the beginning of July and October (iv) Quarterly project narrative report developed by 10 July and 10 October

Q3 2016 (i) As a part of the start-up phase, the following results were delivered: - Completion of 8 ERRY project staff recruited. The remaining post is the Solar Energy Project Manager. The post was originally advertised as the Solar Energy Specialist. While the final candidate was identified by the end of May, the project management structure for the Solar Energy Component was changed and thus the TOR of the post was adjusted and advertised again in June. The Livelihood Restoration Team is responsible for the recruitment (it is estimated to complete by the end of August). - Based on the criteria in the Description of Action, target districts were shortlisted (5-7 districts/governorate). In consultation with Governorate offices, UNDP's target districts were agreed with them (the final list of the UNDP's target districts were uploaded as attachment in ATLAS). (ii) UNDP's 2016 annual report was developed and submitted to the ERRY Joint Programme Manager in June, which is uploaded in ATLAS attachment tab) (iii) Issue and risk log was reviewed in the Djibouti workshop and reflected in ATLAS (off line issue and risk log was also uploaded in ATLAS) (iv) a first draft of quarterly project report will be send to the Programme Officer by 10 July.

(i) Completion of start-up/launching the project within Q2 2016 as agreed in the Dead Sea Workshop (ii) Quarterly work plan review (iii) Quarterly issues and risk log update (iv) Quarterly project narrative report
- Quarterly work plan reviewed - Quarterly issues and risk log updated - Quarterly project narrative report finalized

description.narrative: Enhanced Rural Energy Resilience communities benefit from solar energy for sustainable livelihoods opportunities
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Communities benefit from improved and more sustainable livelihoods opportunities through better access to solar energy

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1- Seven solar energy resilience building programming initiatives formulated and implemented. 2- At least 100 rural communities will improve their access to solar energy. 3- Introduction of solar energy applications to improve performance of 12 economically productive assets. 4- Solar energy market mix conducted and networking developed among solar dealers.

comment.narrative:
- Map rural energy insecurity gap in the targeted governorates
- Design a phased out road map for technical installation of feasible communal solar energy services to improve access to basic social services

- Socio-Economic and Energy Assessment was conducted in Hajjah, Lahej, Hodaida and Abyan. The assessment objective is to collect and review available information and data on the socio-economic context, the basic social services and communal facilities and the key productive community assets in the targeted districts. The assessment also identified the most vulnerable and energy insecure groups and communities, energy gaps and needs for sustainable operation of prioritized key services of the social services and communal facilities.
-Short and medium terms priorities have been identified with stakeholders for health units and schools. - Design of technical installation of solar energy social services i.e. solar lanterns, solar powered street lights completed for 2016 where 800 household solar units and 2 solar market places will be powered with solar energy. - Procurement process for supply, delivery and installation of solar energy systems completed to provide solar energy systems to 20 health units and 20 schools

3 technical assessments and studies on solar business development, marketing mix and best parties in solar energy conducted
76 social services and 12 productive assets provided with solar energy systems
1600 solar lanterns will be provided to the most vulnerable households in the targeted districts.
Capacity building and awareness raising programmes implemented

- 3 technical assessments and studies on solar business development, market mix and best practices in South-South cooperation in solar energy conducted. The assessment on South-South cooperation is completed , the two other are ongoing - 74 social services and 9 productive assets provided with solar energy systems- ongoing - 2400 solar lanterns will be provided to the most vulnerable households in the targeted districts. - 4 drinking water solar pumping systems procured and installed. - Capacity building and awareness raising programmes implemented.

Outcome 1: OUTPUT 1.2. # 3 solar energy resilience initiatives formulated #36 rural communities have improved access to solar energy #8 economically productive assets improved
#2 assessments on solar business development and market mix conducted and implemented

comment.narrative: Around 18.8 million people in need of livelihoods support, including access to income opportunities and key essential services – including 10.3 million in acute needs (2017)

- Launching the project activities and recruitment of project staff - Needs assessment conducted to identify the health facilities that need rehabilitation and solar equipment. - Needs assessment carried out to identify the targeted districts for cash for work , sub-projets are identified and direct beneficiaries are enrolled in CFW and asset upgrade. - Damage Assessments conducted by VCCs and DMTs.

The project has been launched successfully during the 3rd quarter and LOA was finalized with the implementing partner (SFD). Preparation for the needs assessments for the identification of health facilities and targeted districts for cash for work is ongoing. Recruitment of project staff is ongoing
